ARKEMA COATING RESINS (ACR)

12840 SOUTH PULASKI ROAD

ALSIP, ILLINOIS  60803

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY







1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response

     Policies



The ARKEMA COATING RESINS (ACR) Alsip Plant is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We have implemented a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment.  These programs include both Arkema Coating Resins Responsible Care requirements and governmental requirements, such as the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) rule and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.



2. Description of the Facility and Regulated Substance



The ARKEMA COATING RESINS (ACR) Alsip Plant is a manufacturing facility that produces synthetic latex polymer products, which are sold to customers that convert them into finished products such as latex paint, caulk and adhesives.  The RMP rule requires that if a facility, such as the Alsip Plant, has a specific amount (threshold) or more of any one of 140 toxic and flammable chemicals, the facility must follow the RMP rule requirements for that chemicals.  The ACR Alsip Plant has the following RMP-regulated toxic substance at levels above threshold quantities: 



Vinyl Acetate Monomer (Acetic acid ethenyl ester)





The Alsip Plant does not utilize any chemicals on the RMP-regulated list of flammable substances.



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program 



Our general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA RMP rule and OSHA's PSM standard.  Key elements include:



Equipment Design:  Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmen

tal requirements.



Process Safety Information: Chemical hazards, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.



Process Hazard Analysis:  Process hazard analyses are conducted every five years to identify major process hazard scenarios and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.  The PHA process incorporates Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) which uses semi-quantitative assessment techniques to ensure that controls used for prevention or mitigation of hazards provide adequate protection.



Operating Procedures:  Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are maintained up-to-date.



Operator Training/Certification Program:  The plant has training and testing program which provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.



Technical Staff Training and Support:  Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours a day to support operations.



Maintenance Procedures:  The plant has specific procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely.



Maintenance Training:  The plant trains persons who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks on process equipment.



Mechanical Integrity Program:  Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.



Task List is a database systems and SAP that generate reminders designed to ensure that process safety information is kept up-to-date.



Management of Change:  The plant has a management system to ensure that modified facilities and processes will be safe to operate.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews:  Reviews are conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified facilities and processes are safe for operation.

Incident Investigation:  The plant has a program to ensure that accidents and incidents are properly investigated to determine the cause(s) and to implement corrective action(s) that are needed to prevent the event from reoccurring.



Employee Participation:  The plant has a program to involve employees in prevention program elements.



Hot Work Permit:  The plant has a procedure to ensure that welding, cutting and brazing are safely performed in areas where flammable or combustible material may be present.



Contractor Safety Program:  The plant has a program to ensure that contractors are properly trained and perform their work in compliance with safety requirements.



Compliance Audits:  Periodic Corporate, Business and plant-led audits are conducted to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and Arkema requirements.



These general prevention elements and the chemical-specific steps discussed in the previous section are parts of an overall management system to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standards that these management systems set.  We have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.



4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



In the last five years there has not been an accident or incident involving an EPA RMP chemical at the Arkema Coating Resins Alsip Plant that resulted in an on-site death, injury, or property damage; or a known off-site death, injury, evacuation, shelter-in-place, property damage or environmental damage.



5. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The ARKEMA COATING RESINS (ACR) Alsip Plant maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedur

es address all aspects of emergency response, including:



   Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures.



   Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation.



   Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.



   Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.



   Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment.



The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.





Site Emergency Drills:

Plant team performs routine Emergency drills on various scenarios throughout the year. Drill schedule is established in the beginning of the year and communicated to shift team lead for guidance on scenarios. Site consider various factors while establishing drill schedule such as guidance from corporate guidelines, potential high risk process, past events or incidents etc. Each shift performs 4 drills annually, one drill per quarter. Site also work with Alsip Fire Department to schedule site wide annual drill, which may involve Haz mat team, Alsip police department. All all site employees, contractors working on the site participate in site wide drills. Depending on the drill-scenario and availability of other nearby township Fire departments also join the drill. Some of the drill scenarios site coordinated with fire department and Hazmat team are run-away reaction in the reactor-causing spill and injury, vapor cloud caused by inadvertent mixing of raw material in the monomer storage tank causing runaway reaction and rupture of the tank or rupture disk etc. 



6. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



On-going programs, such as Process Hazard Analysis evaluations, continually aim to improve process safety. This facility upgraded and installed new DCS (Distributed Control System) system to improve process performance in December 2019, which will also improve Process Safety and reliability.
